docs.lead_paragraph: BOEING BECOMES PARTNER IN SATELLITE COMPANY The Boeing Company announced yesterday that it has become a minority partner in SkyBridge, a satellite communications company, and that the two companies had agreed to launch six satellites starting in 2002. SkyBridge, largely controlled by the European space industry leader Alcatel, will use the six launchings to place 40 satellites into orbit. The company eventually hopes to have a constellation of 80 communications satellites, to be used for telecommunications and Internet-like data transmissions. Terms were not disclosed. (AP) MAKER OF GEAR-PRODUCTION EQUIPMENT AGREES TO BUYOUT The Gleason Corporation, a maker of gear-production equipment, agreed to be sold for about $332 million in cash and debt in a management-led buyout to take the company private. Gleason shareholders will receive $23 a share, a 28 percent premium to Wednesday's closing price. The proposed buyers are James S. Gleason, the chairman; senior management; and the Gleason Foundation, which together own about 15 percent of the company, along with the New York buyout firm Vestar Capital Partners. Sales of the company, which is based in Rochester, have dropped 18 percent through the third quarter because of lower domestic demand for metalworking equipment. Gleason shares rose $5.50, to $23.50, yesterday. (Bloomberg News) BAKER HUGHES SAYS ACCOUNTING ERRORS WILL BE COSTLY Baker Hughes Inc. shares fell 15 percent yesterday after the company said accounting discrepancies at its Inteq drilling technology unit could cost it $40 million to $50 million before taxes. Baker Hughes, the No. 3 oil-field services company, said the accounting errors led it to postpone a $200 million bond sale. The company had planned to use the proceeds to refinance debt and pay for a ship used for undersea oil exploration. Earnings from earlier quarters may have to be restated, Baker Hughes said. The company, which is based in Houston, did not say which quarters would be affected. Baker Hughes shares fell $3.25, to $19.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. (Bloomberg News) TITAN AGREES TO BUY ADVANCED COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS The Titan Corporation, a satellite communications and information-technology company, agreed to buy Advanced Communication Systems Inc., a rival that primarily does work for the government, for about $175 million in stock. Titan said it would pay about $20 for each share of Advanced Communication. Shares in Advanced Communication, which is based in Fairfax, Va., rose $3.25, to $17.75. Titan, based in San Diego, fell 25 cents, to $28.4375, on the New York Stock Exchange. (Bloomberg News) PUMA TECHNOLOGY TO BUY INTERNET SOFTWARE CREATOR Shares of Puma Technology Inc., a maker of software for mobile devices, rose 11 percent after it agreed to buy NetMind Technologies for about $370 million in stock. Puma said late Wednesday that it would swap five million common shares for closely held NetMind, which is based in Campbell, Calif., to gain software that alerts Internet users to content. The company said it expected to complete the purchase by April 30. Yesterday, its shares rose $8.50, to $82.75. Puma, based in San Jose, Calif., plans to combine the software with its Web-browsing and synchronization technology. (Bloomberg News) BROADBASE TO BUY MAKER OF ONLINE MARKETING SOFTWARE Broadbase Software Inc., a maker of software for integrating and analyzing customer data, said yesterday that it agreed to buy Rubric Inc. for $331.2 million in stock to acquire software for automating online marketing. Broadbase will issue about 3.6 million common shares to the stockholders of closely held Rubric. Broadbase, which is based in Menlo Park, Calif., specializes in customer relationship management software that lets businesses use information to tailor Internet ads, aim at ''profitable'' customers, or conduct cross-selling. Shares of Broadbase fell $3.4375, to $92. The announcement was made after the close of trading in the United States. (Bloomberg News) WAL-MART SELLING ITS OWN BRAND OF ALKALINE BATTERIES Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the world's largest retailer, has started to sell alkaline batteries under its own label, competing with brands sold by the Gillette Company's Duracell and the Rayovac Corporation, among others. Wal-Mart introduced the EvrActiv store brand, with six packs of AA and AAA batteries priced at $3.37 each, in mid-November. Since then, it has added the line to virtually all of its 2,485 United States stores, a spokesman, John Bisio, said. (Bloomberg News) WELLPOINT AGREES TO ACQUIRE HEALTH INSURER IN ILLINOIS WellPoint Health Networks Inc., one of California's largest health insurers, agreed to buy Rush Prudential Health Plans for about $200 million to add more customers in Illinois. Rush Prudential, owned by Rush-Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center and Prudential Insurance Company of America, is one of Chicago's biggest health-benefits companies. WellPoint, which already has more than 283,000 medical customers in Illinois, said the state was a growth market. Rush Prudential had 302,775 medical plan members as of Sept. 30, the company said. The transaction needs regulatory approval and is expected to close in the first quarter. Shares of WellPoint, which is based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., fell 81.25 cents, to $59.3125. The acquisition was announced after the close of regular United States trading. (Bloomberg News) FUSION MEDICAL TECHNOLOGIES PRODUCT GIVEN APPROVAL Fusion Medical Technologies, a money-losing company whose shares have doubled this year, won Food and Drug Administration approval for its most important product, a gel used to stop bleeding during surgery. Known as FloSeal, it would be the company's only product on the domestic market. FloSeal combines a collagen-based gel and thrombin, a potent blood-clotting agent. It will be used in surgery on the heart, blood vessels and spine, especially where sutures, staples and fibrin glues do not close wounds well. The company, which had no revenue last year, will market the product for use in spinal surgery with Sulzer Medica, Europe's biggest maker of orthopedic products. Shares in Fusion, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., fell 93.75 cents, to $13.0625. (Bloomberg News) SFX MARKETING SIGNS SPONSORSHIP DEAL WITH BUDWEISER Budweiser beer and SFX Marketing Inc., a concert promoter, said yesterday that they signed a three-year partnership establishing Budweiser as the exclusive beer sponsor of SFX events. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. As sponsor, Budweiser will receive brand mentions in SFX-produced local television, print and radio advertising, and in on-site signs and program advertisements. Budweiser is made by the Anheuser-Busch Companies. Shares in Anheuser-Busch were off 87.5 cents at $73.125. (Reuters) USA NETWORKS INC., New York, a media and electronic-commerce business, said it had agreed to buy Ingenious Designs Inc., Edgewood, N.Y., a maker of infomercials and products sold via direct-response television. Financial terms were not disclosed. GAYLORD ENTERTAINMENT CO., Nashville, has bought the golf champion Jack Nicklaus's majority interest in Jack Nicklaus Productions, Los Angeles. Terms of the sale of the privately held company were not disclosed. ETOYS INC., Santa Monica, Calif., the No. 1 Internet toy retailer, agreed to sell its consumer health interactive unit for $20 million in cash and stock to an investment group led by J. H. Whitney & Co., Stamford, Conn., a private equity firm. EASTMAN KODAK CO., Rochester, the largest photography company, increased the amount of stock it may buy back this year by $200 million, or 29 percent, to help lift its share price. Kodak raised its repurchase program to $900 million from $700 million.

The acquisition was announced after the close of regular United States trading.

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's news conference today in the Dean Acheson Auditorium at the State Department, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription company: Opening Statement We are at a pivotal moment in the Middle East peace process, one that can shape the face of the region for generations to come. As I have said on numerous occasions, history will not forgive a failure to seize this opportunity to achieve a comprehensive peace. We've made good progress on the Palestinian track, and I am determined to help Prime Minister Barak and Chairman Arafat move forward in accordance with their very ambitious timetable.

headline.main: Clinton's Words to Press: On the Mideast, Chechnya and Other Matters

docs.lead_paragraph: Negotiators for Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature are considering an increase in the state's cigarette tax of at least 25 cents a pack to pay for a health care plan that would expand medical coverage for low-income New Yorkers, according to people involved in the discussions. The talks are being driven by several factors: the looming expiration of a state law that imposes surcharges on hospitals bills to pay for care of the poor and the training of young doctors; a consensus in Albany to use a significant part of the money from the national tobacco settlement on health care; and a growing recognition among lawmakers that something should be done for the more than three million uninsured New Yorkers.

headline.main: Albany Lawmakers Consider Raising Tobacco Tax

docs.abstract: Negotiators for Gov George E Pataki and Legislature are considering increase in state's cigarette tax of at least 25 cents pack to pay for health care plan that would expand medical coverage for low-income New Yorkers; at center of negotiations is state law that adds $2.6 billion in surcharges to hospital bills, largely to help hospitals train doctors who are just out of medical school, and to care for poor people who are not insured; law expires on Dec 31, and it would be crushing financial blow to state's hospitals if it were not renewed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: One of Connecticut's largest health care providers has agreed to pay $74 million for distributing millions of dollars in unnecessary Medicare payments to hospitals in the late 1980's and early 90's, federal investigators announced today. The amount represents the largest fraud settlement related to health care in the state's history, they said, and is the second-largest fraud settlement in the country involving a Medicare contractor.

headline.main: Medicare Fraud Case Is Settled for $74 Million

docs.abstract: Federal investigators say Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Connecticut has agreed to pay $74 million for distributing millions of dollars in unnecessary Medicare payments to hospitals in late 1980's and early 90's; amount represents largest fraud settlement related to health care in state and is second-largest fraud settlement in US involving Medicare contractor (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury Secretary and one of the architects of the current economic expansion, vouching for his fiscal wisdom and discipline, Vice President Al Gore continued today to attack his opponents as fiscally irresponsible. Mr. Gore said the budget proposals of former Senator Bill Bradley, his rival for the Democratic presidential nomination, and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the leading Republican, would take ''unnecessary risks with our prosperity.''

headline.main: With Endorsements, Gore and Bradley Promote Plans on Economy and Health

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore wins endorsement of former Treas Sec Robert E Rubin and rival Bill Bradley endorsements of former Federal Reserve chairman Paul Volcker and economist Henry Kaufman, president of financial consulting firm; Gore criticizes economic policies of Bradley and Republican frontrunner, Texas Gov George Bush as fiscally irresponsible; says both would take unnecessary risks with nation's posterity; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Israel to Halt Expansion Of West Bank Settlements Prime Minister Ehud Barak sought to defuse growing tensions with the Palestinians by pledging to halt further expansion of Jewish settlements in the West Bank. He spoke shortly before Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright was to arrive for separate meetings with Mr. Barak and Yasir Arafat. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: A sweeping national study of homeless people served by shelters, soup kitchens and other programs has found that almost half were in their first episode of homelessness, 44 percent had worked at least part time in the previous month and 42 percent said that what they needed more than anything was help finding a job. But the study, being released today and based on Census Bureau surveys in 1995 and 1996 and the most comprehensive study of homelessness ever, also found that over all, the homeless were deeply impoverished and most were ill. Two-thirds were suffering from chronic or infectious diseases, not counting AIDS, 55 percent lacked health insurance, and 39 percent had signs of mental illness. Twenty-seven percent reported a childhood history of foster care or institutional placement.

headline.main: Deep Poverty and Illness Found Among Homeless

docs.abstract: Sweeping and most comprehensive national study of homeless people ever, prepared by Urban Institute and based on Census Bureau surveys in 1995 and 1996, finds that over all, homeless are deeply impoverished and that most are ill; findings detailed; Andrew M Cuomo, secretary of Housing and Urban Development, comments; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton issued her first direct policy challenge against her likely Senate race opponent yesterday, calling on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to express a position on a bill that would increase the number of people eligible for benefits under the Family and Medical Leave Act. Shrugging off the challenge, Mr. Giuliani responded by saying that he generally agreed with Mrs. Clinton's position and would likely support an expansion of the law.

headline.main: For First Time, Mrs. Clinton Directly Challenges Giuliani
